CSUS124.name: Introduction to Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
CSUS124.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSUS124.description: Contemporary research and movements involving agricultural and food system sustainability. Socio-cultural factors influencing food and agriculture.
CSUS124.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSUS200.name: Introduction to Sustainability
CSUS200.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSUS200.description: Introduction to sustainability and personal role in sustainability initiatives. Implications of individual actions for key sustainability challenges. Application of sustainability principles and leadership skills in community.

CSUS207.name: Great Lakes: Biology and Management
CSUS207.description: Living aquatic resources of the Great Lakes, environmental history, and biological resources and their management. Policy issues.

CSUS215.name: International Development and Sustainability
CSUS215.description: Theories, concepts and themes in international development and sustainability.

CSUS221.name: Seminar in Environmental and Sustainability Careers
CSUS221.description: Societal value of, and opportunities in, environment and sustainability careers. Career planning, including engagement with employers and alumni.
CSUS221.restrictions: Open to students in the Environmental Studies and Sustainability Major or approval of department.

CSUS222A.name: Seminar in Instructional Theory I - Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Education
CSUS222A.description: Professional involvement and introductory instructional theory in formal and non formal agriculture, food and natural resources education. Requires 10 hours of observation in a K-12 Ag, Food, and Natural Resource Education (AFNRE) classroom.

CSUS222B.name: Seminar in Instructional Theory II - Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Education
CSUS222B.description: Principles of experiential learning theory in formal and nonformal agriculture, food and natural resources education. Requires 10 hours of observation in a K-12 Ag, Food, and Natural Resource Education (AFNRE) classroom.

CSUS222C.name: Seminar in Instructional Theory III - Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Education
CSUS222C.description: Application of problem-based learning theory in formal and nonformal agriculture, food and natural resources education. Requires 10 hours of observation in a K-12 Ag, Food, and Natural Resource Educational (AFNRE) classroom.

CSUS223A.name: Seminar in Leadership Theory I - Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Education
CSUS223A.description: Introductory leadership theory in formal and nonformal agriculture, food and natural resources education.

CSUS223B.name: Seminar in Leadership Theory II - Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Education
CSUS223B.description: Practical applications of leadership theory in agriculture, food and natural resources education within Michigan communities.

CSUS223C.name: Seminar in Leadership Theory III - Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Education
CSUS223C.description: Applied mentoring and leadership evaluation in formal and nonformal agriculture, food, and natural resources education.

CSUS224.name: Sustainable Farm and Food Systems Field Studies
CSUS224.description: Field visits to farm and food system operations that utilize sustainable practices in Michigan. Offered first half of semester.
CSUS224.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or agricultural technology students.

CSUS250.name: Global Issues in Agriculture and Natural Resources
CSUS250.description: Globalization. Economic, political, and social issues related to natural resources and agricultural production. Historical perspectives and future projections.
CSUS250.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

CSUS259.name: Sustainable Energy and Society
CSUS259.description: Sustainable fuels and technologies, energy systems, energy transitions, and personal and societal roadblocks to achieving sustainable energy. Energy poverty, justice and decision-making.

CSUS265.name: Exploring Environmental and Sustainability Issues and Policy Using Film
CSUS265.description: Environmental and sustainability issues, themes, and perspectives in feature films and documentaries.

CSUS273.name: Introduction to Travel and Tourism
CSUS273.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSUS273.description: Overview of the travel and tourism industry. History, scope and management of the tourism system. Tourism demand, destination management, major travel segments, tourism marketing.

CSUS276.name: Sustaining Our National Parks and Recreation Lands
CSUS276.description: Scope, history and management of federal, state and local public recreation lands. Future management options strengthening sustainability. Careers in natural resource recreation.

CSUS278.name: Introduction to Conservation, Recreation and Environmental Enforcement
CSUS278.description: Scope, history and application of conservation, recreation and environmental law enforcement at the international, federal, state and local level. Integration with traditional policing, resource management and public lands. Career opportunities.

CSUS300.name: Theoretical Foundations of Sustainability
CSUS300.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSUS300.description: Foundations of sustainability theory. History and evolution of interdisciplinary thought about sustainability. Principles of systems thinking as applied to complex problems. Application of theory in community systems.
CSUS300.prerequisite: ((CSUS 200) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (EC 201 or EC 202)
CSUS300.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or approval of department.

CSUS301.name: Community Engagement for Sustainability (W)
CSUS301.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSUS301.description: Application of principles of change theory, citizenship, sustainability, and community engagement at multiple scales. Public and participatory decision making in diverse contexts. Techniques and skills for community engagement. Examination of personal identities as citizens. Leadership and communication challenges in active practice of engagement.
CSUS301.prerequisite: (CSUS 200) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

CSUS310.name: History of Environmental Thought and Sustainability
CSUS310.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS310.description: History of attitudes and values associated with the environment, wilderness, environmentalism, conservation, preservation, and sustainability. Perceptions and assessment of modern environmental problems and issues.
CSUS310.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
CSUS310.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors.

CSUS320.name: Environmental Planning and Management
CSUS320.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS320.description: Concepts, principles and objectives of planning and management. Demand, supply and impacts of natural resources use. Suitability assessment for sustainable development and land use planning.
CSUS320.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

CSUS322.name: Leadership for Community Sustainability
CSUS322.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSUS322.description: Leadership theory, practice, and reflection. Individual and team leadership in the context of community sustainability.
CSUS322.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

CSUS343.name: Community Food and Agricultural Systems
CSUS343.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS343.description: Food and agricultural systems. Inputs, production, processing, distribution, consumption and disposal. Industrialization, globalization and centralization of power. Community goals including ecological sustainability, social justice, economic viability and democracy.
CSUS343.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

CSUS354.name: Water Resources Management
CSUS354.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSUS354.description: Biophysical, community, and institutional components of comprehensive water resources management. Biophysical and social processes that control the quality and quantity of aquatic resources at the watershed level.
CSUS354.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

CSUS418.name: Community Sustainability Study Abroad
CSUS418.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS418.description: Study and travel experience emphasizing contemporary problems in sustainability in world, national, and local communities.

CSUS419.name: International Studies in Community Sustainability
CSUS419.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS419.description: Contemporary problems affecting community sustainability outside the United States. Ecological, socio-dynamic, and cultural influences on environmental management. Study-travel experience.
CSUS419.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. Approval of department; application required.

CSUS424.name: Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems: Integration and Synthesis
CSUS424.description: Biogeochemical and socio-economic aspects of food, fiber, and fuel production. Environmental impacts and social context. Experiential learning projects.
CSUS424.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSUS425.name: Environmental Impact Assessment
CSUS425.description: Environmental impact assessment of proposed and built projects and plans. Regulatory frameworks and implementation issues.
CSUS425.prerequisite: ((CSUS 200 or CSS 210 or GEO 206 or GLG 201) or approval of department) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CSUS425.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Community Sustainability or approval of department.

CSUS429.name: Program Evaluation for Community Sustainability
CSUS429.description: Concepts, theories, and procedures in program evaluation. Practical methods and skills to plan and implement evaluations of community, agriculture, and natural resources programs.
CSUS429.prerequisite: {{(MTH 103) and (STT 200 or STT 201)} or (MTH 103 and MTH 114) or MTH 116 or MTH 124} and ((CSUS 200 or EEM 255) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

CSUS430.name: Non-Profit Organizational Management for Community Sustainability
CSUS430.description: Sustainable management and operation of non-profit organizations. Legal foundations, policy, funding, management responsibilities, ethical decision-making and management functions.
CSUS430.prerequisite: (CSUS 200 or CSUS 273 or CSUS 276) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CSUS430.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSUS431.name: Interpretation and Visitor Information Systems
CSUS431.description: Interpretation principles and practice for nonformal settings, such as community development organizations, parks, museums, zoos, aquaria, nature and visitor centers, and historic sites. Goals and functions of interpretation for community development, visitor and tourist experience enhancement, achievement of resource and visitor management goals. Planning, implementation, and evaluation of interpretive programs for diverse audiences. Information systems and visitor services. National certification optional. Field trips required.
CSUS431.prerequisite: ((CSUS 200 or CSUS 276) or approval of department) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CSUS431.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSUS433.name: Grant Writing and Fund Development
CSUS433.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSUS433.description: Theoretical and practical background for proposal writing. Program and strategic planning. Fund-raising and organizational advancement.
CSUS433.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
CSUS433.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSUS445.name: Community-Based Environmental and Sustainability Education
CSUS445.description: Methods, materials and theory for non-formal environmental and sustainability education. Focuses on non-profit and agency education programming in conservation, food systems, parks and recreation, and community engagement and outreach. Consideration of relationships among non-formal, informal and K-12 education systems. Field trips required.
CSUS445.prerequisite: (CSUS 200 or approval of department) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CSUS445.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSUS446.name: Environmental Issues and Public Policy
CSUS446.description: Interrelationship of science and public policy in resolving environmental issues. Technical, social, economic, and legal influences. Case study approach.
CSUS446.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

CSUS447.name: Community Economic Development
CSUS447.description: Theories, frameworks, policies, concepts, principles, models, and skills for community economic development. Community participation in local development initiatives.

CSUS453.name: Watershed Planning and Management
CSUS453.description: Foundations of watershed planning and management in the United States. Physical, chemical and socioeconomic conditions; legal, financial and institutional dimensions; management alternatives; stakeholders; educational campaigns; evaluation.

CSUS463.name: Food Fight: Politics of Food
CSUS463.description: Social power and its influence in US agrifood system. Structural and cultural issues related to politics of food consumption, production, labor, processing, retail, techno-science, policy, resistance movements.
CSUS463.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

CSUS464.name: Environmental and Natural Resource Policy in Michigan
CSUS464.description: State legislative process and its role in environmental and natural resource policy formulation. Influence of lobbying, citizen engagement and political factors.
CSUS464.prerequisite: CSUS 200 or EEM 255 or approval of department

CSUS465.name: Environmental and Natural Resource Law
CSUS465.description: Legal principles and process related to the environment and natural resources. Common law, constitutional law, statutory and administrative law.
CSUS465.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSUS473.name: Social Entrepreneurship and Community Sustainability
CSUS473.description: Start-up and management of private sector, non-profit, and public organizations. Identifying and overcoming the challenges associated with the sustainable operations of small organizations.
CSUS473.prerequisite: (CSUS 200 or CSUS 273) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CSUS473.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSUS474.name: Advanced Topics in Tourism Management
CSUS474.description: Tourism as a form of economic and community development. Tourism planning, marketing and management. Tourism and sustainability. Tourism research.
CSUS474.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSUS476.name: Natural Resource Recreation Management
CSUS476.description: Natural resource recreation management principles, tools and models. Applications to trail, camping, watercraft and dispersed recreation settings. Security of visitors, resources and facilities. Case studies and integrated problem solving. Offered first half of semester.
CSUS476.prerequisite: (CSUS 276 or FOR 101 or FOR 202 or FW 101) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CSUS476.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSUS489.name: Seminar in Zoo and Aquarium Science
CSUS489.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSUS489.description: Scientific writing and oral presentations related to zoo and aquarium studies.

CSUS490.name: Independent Study in Community Sustainability
CSUS490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS490.description: Individual supervised study of selected topics

CSUS491.name: Special Topics in Community Sustainability
CSUS491.description: Selected issues in community sustainability derived from current and emerging topics of interest.

CSUS493.name: Professional Internship in Community Sustainability
CSUS493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS493.description: Off campus supervised capstone professional experience in an organization related to student’s major in the Department of Community Sustainability
CSUS493.prerequisite: (CSUS 200) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CSUS493.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Department of Community Sustainability. Approval of department; application required. A student may earn a maximum of 6 credits in all enrollments for any or all of these courses

CSUS800.name: Foundations of Community Sustainability I
CSUS800.description: Theoretical and conceptual foundations of community sustainability. Sustainability practice. Introduction to ethics and community engagement for sustainability. Field trips required.
CSUS800.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Community Sustainability.

CSUS801.name: Foundations of Community Sustainability II
CSUS801.description: Applications of sustainability science and systems thinking for community engagement. Boundary-crossing and organizations. Social change. Sustainability ethics. Facilitation of participatory community processes. Participatory virtues for sustainability. Group dynamics in interdisciplinary and community contexts.
CSUS801.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Community Sustainability.

CSUS802.name: Introduction to Interdisciplinary Inquiry
CSUS802.description: Interdisciplinary, multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary research design. Community engagement as related to research and inquiry. Practical skills for developing inquiry projects.
CSUS802.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Community Sustainability.

CSUS805.name: Proposal Development for Interdisciplinary Inquiry
CSUS805.description: Preparation of proposals for inquiry in practical and research settings. Application of inquiry concepts and practices in designing projects or research. Professional oral and written communications in sustainability inquiry. Processes of peer support and critique. Offered first ten weeks of semester.
CSUS805.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Community Sustainability.

CSUS811.name: Community, Food and Agriculture: A Survey
CSUS811.description: Philosophical, socio-economic, health and political issues related to food and farming in the United States.

CSUS814.name: Sustainable Tourism and Protected Area Management: Theories and Applications
CSUS814.description: Historical antecedents and current concepts of leisure, travel, and tourism. Tourism theory and applications.

CSUS816.name: Environmental Design Theory
CSUS816.description: Differences between normative theories, scientific theories, models, and constructs. Exploration of normative theories related to thesis or practicum.

CSUS823.name: Contemporary Issues in Animal-Human Relationships
CSUS823.description: Contemporary issues in animal-human relationships, including agriculture and food systems, local communities, and enclosed parks. Nature as a fluid network of relations including humans, nonhumans, and technologies.

CSUS824.name: Sustainable Development
CSUS824.description: Measurement of social and economic welfare at national and local scales. Consumption and economic growth as welfare indicators. Theories of development, utility, and economic growth. Indicators of sustainable development. Environmental and social dimensions of human well-being.

CSUS826.name: International Development: Theory and Practice
CSUS826.description: Evolution of international development theory across disciplines. Changing conceptualizations, measurements, processes and effects of development and poverty. Ethnicity, social class, gender, and community influences on socioeconomic processes. Current issues, concerns, and strategic alternatives.

CSUS829.name: Economics of Environmental Resources
CSUS829.description: Economic principles, theoretical models, and empirical methods related to environmental problems and policy interventions. Applications to air, land, water, forests, energy, fish and wildlife, and climate change, including in developing countries.

CSUS831.name: Foundations of Qualitative Research
CSUS831.description: Qualitative project design. Relationship of epistemology to theory, methodology, and method. Collection and analysis of qualitative data. Project-based. In-depth interviews, focus groups, observation, memos, coding displays, report writing.

CSUS833.name: Program Evaluation in Agriculture and Natural Resources
CSUS833.description: Concepts, theories, procedures and applications of program evaluation. Planning and implementing evaluations of food, agriculture and natural resources programs. Logic models, evaluation plans and instruments, data analysis and written reports.

CSUS834.name: Survey Research and Design
CSUS834.description: Theory and practice of designing and conducting surveys in the study of community sustainability.
CSUS834.restrictions: Open to graduate students or approval of department.

CSUS836.name: Modeling Natural Resource Systems
CSUS836.description: System dynamics modeling in human-environment systems. Sustainability applications, including renewable and non-renewable resource use, greenhouse gas emissions and climate change, pollutants and limits to growth.

CSUS838.name: Participatory Modes of Inquiry
CSUS838.description: Participatory and action research literature across the disciplines. Epistemological and theoretical foundations, fields of application, points of emphasis for practice. Skill building in reflexivity, surfacing assumptions, dialogue, and active listening.

CSUS848.name: Community Based Natural Resource Management in International Development
CSUS848.description: Community-based natural resource management in developing countries. Determinants of conservation, productivity, and income distribution. Interaction of human and natural systems, perceptions of scarcity, property rights, collective action, and governance. Policy tools for promoting conservation.

CSUS855.name: Political Ecology of Food
CSUS855.description: Interactions between food, society and the environment. Ecological impacts and sociopolitical power in international and domestic contexts.
CSUS855.restrictions: Open to graduate students or approval of department.

CSUS858.name: Gender, Justice and Environmental Change : Issues and Concepts
CSUS858.description: Issues and concepts related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Key debates and theoretical approaches to addressing environmental issues from a gender and social justice perspective. Gender and environment issues and processes from a global perspective.

CSUS859.name: Gender, Justice, and Environmental Change: Methods and Application
CSUS859.description: Methods and case studies related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Methodological and fieldwork issues from a feminist perspective in international and intercultural contexts. Qualitative and quantitative methods for integrating social and environmental data.

CSUS860.name: Youth Leadership: Theory and Practice
CSUS860.description: Foundations of theory and practice in youth leadership. Youth development and leadership in families, schools, organizations, and communities. Review of youth organizations at the local, state, national, and international levels. Field trips required.

CSUS861.name: Educational Theory and Application of Experiential Learning in AFNR
CSUS861.description: Foundations of experiential learning in theory and practice. Experiential learning within the context of families, schools, organizations and communities as a function of an educational system. Application of experiential learning within formal and nonformal educational settings. Field trips required.

CSUS863.name: Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Education Laboratory Instruction: Theory and Practice
CSUS863.description: Research-based pedagogy and application of laboratory experiences in teaching and learning. Current principles and practice in AFNRE laboratory learning in formal and non-formal education. Field trips required.

CSUS864.name: Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Educator Induction
CSUS864.description: Induction and persistence theory and research. Personal development. Professional identity. Curriculum expansion. Teaching method enhancement. Community-centered programming. Program evaluation.

CSUS865.name: Facilitative Leadership
CSUS865.description: Facilitative leadership in groups, organizations and communities. Techniques, processes, and skills for leading groups to generate and prioritize ideas, set goals, and create action plans. Practical experience emphasized.

CSUS873.name: Culture, Communities and Tourism
CSUS873.description: Multi-disciplinary exploration of culture, heritage, cultural landscapes, ecotourism. Contribution of cultural institutions and resources to economy, tourism and community development. Relationship between natural environment and cultural expression. Positive and negative impacts of cultural tourism. Domestic and international examples.

CSUS886.name: Fundamentals of Museum Studies
CSUS886.description: Introduction to the history of museums and current practices, standards, issues and ethics related to education, administration, visitor studies and the development, care and use of museum collections.
CSUS886.restrictions: Open to lifelong graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters or in the Department of Anthropology or in the Department of History. Approval of department.

CSUS890.name: Independent Study in Community Sustainability
CSUS890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS890.description: Supervised individual study in an area of community sustainability or sustainable tourism and protected area management.
CSUS890.restrictions: Open to graduate students. Approval of department.

CSUS891.name: Selected Topics in Community Sustainability
CSUS891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS891.description: Selected topics in community sustainability or sustainable tourism and protected area management of current interest and importance.
CSUS891.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the Department of Community Sustainability or in the Community, Agriculture, Recreation and Resource Studies major. Approval of department.

CSUS891B.name: Advanced Topics in Community, Food and Agriculture
CSUS891B.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS891B.description: Selected, advanced topics in community, food and agriculture.

CSUS894.name: Field Practicum in Community Sustainability
CSUS894.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS894.description: Integration of knowledge, skills and program objectives with field-based scholarship or training in programs in domestic or foreign settings. Practice, observation, and analysis through field experiences. Writing, analysis, and evaluation.
CSUS894.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Community Sustainability.

CSUS897.name: Practicum in Museum Studies
CSUS897.semester: On Demand, On Demand, On Demand

CSUS898.name: Master's Professional Project
CSUS898.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS898.description: Master's project, non-thesis research, practicum or other professional development capstone experiences.
CSUS898.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Department of Community Sustainability.

CSUS899.name: Master's Thesis Research
CSUS899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS899.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Department of Community Sustainability.

CSUS999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
CSUS999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSUS999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Community Sustainability.
